<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">the preacher who was for banishing <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-rhoo" key="Robin Hood">Robin Hood</rs>and such</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">
            <choice>
              <sic>supersitions</sic>
              <corr>superstitions</corr>
            </choice> was forging the very weapon 
            <choice>
              <sic>theat</sic>
              <corr>that</corr>
            </choice> give the old</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">
            <choice>
              <sic>mibstrels</sic>
              <corr>minstrels</corr>
            </choice> a new lease of life. <del hand="ms">His English.</del> When he</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">said the <rs type="literary-work" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#lit-lord" key="Lord's Prayer">Lords prayer</rs> at the beginning and at</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">theend of his 
            <choice>
              <sic>ermon</sic>
              <corr>sermon</corr>
            </choice> he was putting English intpo high places.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">He was rescuing it from the back door. He was teaching</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Spenser and 
            <choice>
              <sic>Shakespere</sic>
              <corr>Shakespeare</corr>
            </choice> how to write.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Both Harrison and Latimer see the very same house <add hand="ms" place="above">[The house was being?]</add></l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">the 
            <choice>
              <sic>hose</sic>
              <corr>house</corr>
            </choice> that was being built on the foundations of the</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">old house. We can still see the great Elizabethan house</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">whose building was to both preacher and antiquary a</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">sign of txmxmxmxmxmxmxmxxx luxury. in all its glory.</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">There it is, standing in its green island of Park 
            <choice>
              <sic>seapareted</sic>
              <corr>separated</corr>
            </choice></l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">often from the high road by only a 
            <choice>
              <sic>d p</sic>
              <corr>dip</corr>
            </choice> in the ground and a</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">low red wall. With its 
            <choice>
              <sic>congloeration</sic>
              <corr>conglomeration</corr>
            </choice> of roofs and chapels</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">and 
            <choice>
              <sic>chimeys</sic>
              <corr>chimneys</corr>
            </choice> 
            <choice>
              <sic>i</sic>
              <corr>it</corr>
            </choice> dwarfs its 
            <choice>
              <sic>neighboyrs</sic>
              <corr>neighbours</corr>
            </choice>. Inside all is kept as</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">if the Queen Elizabeth were expected. The upright 
            <choice>
              <sic>Elizabetahn</sic>
              <corr>Elizabethan</corr>
            </choice></l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">chairs stand round the walls. Their 
            <choice>
              <sic>ftinges</sic>
              <corr>fittings</corr>
            </choice> and tapestry</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">are not much faded. The great oak tables are heavy</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">and polished. The 
            <choice>
              <sic>carbed</sic>
              <corr>carved</corr>
            </choice> chairs and cupboards look 
            <choice>
              <sic>barnd</sic>
              <corr>brand</corr>
            </choice></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">new. The floor is strewn with carpets; cut glass chandeliers</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">hang down from the decorated 
            <choice>
              <sic>pl ter</sic>
              <corr>plaster</corr>
            </choice> work on the 
            <choice>
              <sic>celing</sic>
              <corr>ceiling</corr>
            </choice>.</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Even knick knacks 
            <choice>
              <sic>ha v</sic>
              <corr>have</corr>
            </choice> survived; the inlaid work box,</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">the and the pear shaped 
            <choice>
              <sic>l te</sic>
              <corr>lute</corr>
            </choice> on which the Queen once</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">played.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">But the Elizabethans themselves are silent. Only</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">the furniture remains,, stiff and ornate, fantastic and</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">
            <choice>
              <sic>uncushioned</sic>
              <corr>uncushioned</corr>
            </choice>.</l>
